review.title: Generating Graphical Chain by Mutual Matching of Bayesian Network and Extracted Rules of Bayesian Network Using Genetic Algorithm
review.abstract: With the technology development, the need of analyze and extraction of useful information is increasing. Bayesian networks contain knowledge from data and experts that could be used for decision making processes But they are not easily understandable thus the rule extraction methods have been used but they have high computation costs. To overcome this problem we extract rules from Bayesian network using genetic algorithm. Then we generate the graphical chain by mutually matching the extracted rules and Bayesian network. This graphical chain could shows the sequence of events that lead to the target which could help the decision making process. The experimental results on small networks show that the proposed method has comparable results with brute force method which has a significantly higher computation cost.

sections.heading: IV. PROPOSED METHOD
sections.text: The BN contains useful information and relationships between nodes, but it suffers from complexity resulting from the complete relationships between all nodes. The BN contains a lot of information, but most of them could not be used, because in BN all events are presented with different probabilities, but most of the time we look for the most likely events. In these networks we find the chains with higher probabilities, which could be useful for experts or classifications. In this article we will identify effective chain rules, which could be helpful to understand the events and predict the future events. For example, in the medical field, this knowledge could help the physician to predict the future events caused by present symptoms and by knowing the rules to prevent the fatal disease in the meantime. Finding the optimal chain rules in BN is a NP complete problem, so we use genetic algorithms to find these chain rules. To achieve this goal, we first extract rules from the BN with genetic algorithms and then we extract the rules by extracting the N.

sections.heading: A. Genetic Algorithm
sections.text: The proposed genetic algorithm is based on [2]. This algorithm has two parts with different mutations and crossovers, structural and local. The structural crossover method is applied and only the rules are exchanged between the chromosomes. The genetic algorithm starts with the initialization of the population. Then, the fitness of the chromosomes could be calculated and the parental chromosomes are selected based on the tournament selection method. Children are generated by crossover and mutation to the parental chromosomes. The surviving population is selected by the best children and parents. Finally, a part of the best of the population is sent to the next generation to improve the local search methods and the improved population. In this part, we will introduce the steps of the genetic algorithms used.

sections.heading: B. Generating Graphical Chains
sections.text: Each rule specifies that different nodes affect the target node with which states. To extract the chain, we use the unification of all rule sets in the chromosome. For each effective node, we add an edge with specified labels from that node to its child in the path of that node to the target node (equivalent to BN). Therefore, each rule specifies some effectively labeled edges and their unification is a set of effective chain rules in the BN. Note that for this survey, we use only 0.7 of the threshold, but for this survey we have a weakness.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we propose a new method based on genetic algorithms to extract graphical chain rules, which due to their complexity cannot be extracted directly from the BN. These rules could be useful to analyze the effects of various factors on the disease and help experts to explore more focused factors, as well as to predict the future events caused by the current situation and symptoms. Evaluated results show that the proposed method works in the same way as brute force in small networks. Therefore, this proposed method could also be used for large networks, as it does not suffer from the high complexity of calculating other methods.
